Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Issues in Modeling Gravitational-Wave Sources
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the installation of the upgraded Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) nearing completion, we expect to detect multiple gravitational-wave (GW) sources before the end of the decade. The primary goal of this award is to help ensure that we understand the GW signals as accurately as possible so that we can extract the best science from the expected detections. To do this, the gravitational-wave group at Montclair State University will implement improved waveform templates focusing on (i) binaries with precessing spins, (ii) tidal interactions in binaries containing neutron stars, and (iii) binaries with small orbital eccentricity. These improved templates will be used to quantify the amount of systematic bias in our estimates of the GW source parameters. This bias arises from uncertainties in our knowledge of the actual GW signal. We will also test the effectiveness of simple waveform templates that will search for the GW "memory" effect. The memory is a non-oscillatory piece of the GW signal that is particularly evident in signals from supernova explosions and binary black hole collisions.

Gravitational wave detection provides a new and powerful way to observe some of the most violent events in the universe: the collisions of black holes and neutron stars. Observing these collisions with GWs will test our understanding of Einstein's theory of gravity and also probe aspects of nuclear physics that are inaccessible in terrestrial laboratories (such as the nature of ultra-dense matter). This award will advance the effort to model and understand these collisions with high accuracy. Much of this work will involve the education and training of undergraduate and graduate students. By applying physics, mathematics, computation, and critical thinking to an important scientific problem, these students will acquire technical skills that are in increasingly high demand. Black holes and general relativity continue to fascinate citizens of all ages. This award includes a strong educational outreach component that communicates the excitement of this field to K-12 students, undergraduates, and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant concerned the study of gravitational waves---ripples in the fabric of spacetime produced by colliding black holes and neutron stars. Those waves were detected for the first time in September 2015 by LIGO, the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory. The work supported here focused on the modeling of the gravitational-wave signal from orbiting pairs of black holes or neutron stars. In addition to the research objectives of this work, we initiated significant education and outreach efforts to better inform the public about gravitational-wave science. This grant also supported the training of undergraduate and graduate students.

Although LIGO is a very sensitive detector, extracting detailed information about the source of a gravitational-wave requires a very accurate model for the signal. Improving those models and understanding their implications was a key theme for this work. Important outcomes from the research component include:

Modeling eccentric binaries: Most models of orbiting black holes or neutron stars assume the orbits are circular. However, in some scenarios the orbits could be eccentric when they are first detected by LIGO. We developed a new signal model to describe eccentric binaries provided the eccentricity is small. Compared to alternatives, the model is simple, fully-consistent, and computationally efficient. This model was added to the software that LIGO uses for its analysis. 

Measuring eccentric binaries: Using this model, we then investigated how well LIGO can (in principle) measure eccentricity for a variety of binary systems. We quantified this measureability (which depends on the size of the eccentricity and the sensitivity of LIGO at low frequencies). We also investigated what happens if we ignore eccentricity in our models  when it is in-fact present in the orbit. In this case, a bias is introduced into the mass and spin parameters.

Systematic errors in binary neutron stars: Along with black holes, neutron star binaries are another expected source for LIGO. These systems are particularly interesting because they will tell us about how matter behaves at enormously high densities. But if the gravitational-wave model is missing important ingredients, one will make a systematic error (or bias) when one attempts to determine the value of a system parameter (such as the neutron star mass or a measure of the tidal distortion of the star). We performed a study to quantify the bias in both the mass and tidal parameters as a function of different bias sources. The biases we considered were effects that are often neglected for neutron star systems: the spin of the stars, the orbit eccentricity, and high-order terms in the signal model that are currently unknown.

Modeling and detectability of the gravitational-wave memory: Einstein's theory predicts many nonlinear effects that alter the gravitational-wave signal. One such effect is called the nonlinear "memory". This arises when strong gravitational-waves produce even more waves. The effect manifests itself as a non-oscillating piece of the gravitational-wave signal. The memory is difficult to compute using standard techniques when solving Einstein's equations on the computer. We developed and implemented a semi-analytic technique to compute this memory. Using this we studied how the memory signal varies as a function of the masses in a black hole system. We also investigated how well LIGO and future instruments can detect the memory effect.  

The broader impacts of this grant included several outreach and training activities. Key outcomes in this area include:

Sounds of Spacetime: Because LIGO operates in the same frequency band as the human ear, LIGO signals can be converted to audio and played back. We developed a website based on this "sonification" idea and designed to teach students and the public about gravitational-waves. The website, soundsofspacetime.org, describes of a range of different gravitational-wave source types. It illustrates how changing features of a gravitational-wave source changes the resulting sound. The site also includes detailed pages on the public LIGO detections, including audio representations of the signals that were discovered.

Other Outreach: Other education and outreach work supported by this grant included multiple public lectures on gravitational-waves to school groups, astronomy clubs, or community colleges. We organized exhibit booths on LIGO science at multiple venues. Volunteer science consulting was provided to the TV/film industry (to help improve the scientific realism displayed in those media). As a member of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration, we also supported the education and outreach efforts of that body, including through the management and revision of the ligo.org website. 

Training students: This grant supported the training and mentorship of 6 students at Montclair State University, including 2 graduate (MS degree) students. These students were actively involved in both the research and outreach portions of this award. Students were taught a variety of skills, with emphasis on computation and analysis techniques, understanding the scientific literature, writing and oral presentation, and working in teams. These skills will prepare them for future STEM careers in academia, industry, or government.
